children.name: vote b1
children.definition: vote to formally choose sb such as a political representative or show your support or disapproval of something, for example by putting a mark on a piece of paper in an election: bầu , bỏ phiếu
examples: in tomorrow’s election, many young people will be voting for the first time.
hundreds of people lost their lives in the past fighting for the right to vote.
vote forvote to support them
i haven’t decided who i’m going to vote for.
70% of the population voted for independence.
vote against
only two people voted against the expansion of the business.
vote in favour of sth : bỏ phiếu ủng hộ
the vast majority of people voted in favour of closer links with europe.
vote on : bỏ phiếu về
teachers will be voting on a proposal to accept the 5% pay offer.
vote republican/ labour etcvote for a political party
i’ve voted democrat all my life.
vote[c noun] [b1] an act of voting in an election or meeting, or the choice that you make when you vote: lá phiếu, phiếu bầu
the suggestion was approved, with 25 votes in favour, and 7 against.
a vote for us is not a wasted vote.
the proposal was rejectedby19votes to7.
vote for/ in favour (of)/ against
the house of representatives approved the budget, with 52 votes in favor, 16 against and 12 abstentions.
vote[c noun usually s] [b2] an occasion when a group of people vote in order to decide something or choose a representative : cuộc bỏ phiếu
the results of the vote were surprising – 80% of workers favoured strike action.
vote on
there will be a citywide vote(= all the voters in a particular city )on the matter.

children.name: veto x
children.definition: veto if sb vetoesa decision that other people have agreed on, they use their official power to refuse to allow it: phủ quết bác bỏ
examples: the president has the right to veto any piece of legislation.
the deal was agreed by the board but vetoed by the chairman.

children.name: cast a vote c2
children.definition: cast a vote/ cast a ballot  to vote in a political election: bỏ phiếu (chính trị)
examples: over three quarters of the votes cast were for the liberal candidate.
not until all the ballots have been cast can they be counted.
cast your vote
by the end of the day, less than 40% of the population had cast their votes.

children.name: ballot x
children.definition: ballot to decide sth by asking the members of an organization to formally vote on it: đề nghị (các thành viên) bỏ phiếu
examples: the union will now ballot its members on whether to go ahead with strike action.
the union decided to ballot its members on the issue.

children.name: go to the polls x
children.definition: go to the polls if the people of a country or area go to the polls, they vote in a political election - used especially in newspapers and on television or radio: đi bầu cử
examples: the people of houston will go to the polls next week to elect a new mayor.
with only two days left before france goes to the polls, all parties are campaigning hard.

children.name: the ballot box x
children.definition: the ballot box the system of choosing a government by voting - used especially in newspapers and on television or radio: chế độ bầu cử dân chủ
examples: they are determined to win power through the ballot box, not by violence.
the voters have expressed their views at the ballot box.

children.name: election b1
children.definition: election when people vote to choose a government or leader: cuộc bầu cử
examples: it will be interesting to see what happens at the next election
presidential/ gubernatorial election: bầu cử tổng thống / thống đốc bang
an election to choose a president or governor
america is preparing for the presidential elections, which will take place in two weeks’ time.
general election[uk] [an election to choose a government] tổng tuyển cử
taxation will be one of the major issues at the next general election.
hold an election
south africa held its first multi-racial elections in 1994.
call an electionto say officially that there will be an election : thông báo một cuộc bầu cử
the government may decide to call an election early.
electoral[attri adj] relating to an election: bầu cử
support for electoral reform is growing.
this was the first of her many electoral successes.
electoral systems vary from country to country.
the electoralsystem
electoral law/reform/gains/defeat

children.name: referendum c2
children.definition: referendum when everyone in a country votes on a particular important political subject: cuộc trưng cầu ý dân
examples: how will you be voting in the referendum?
referendum on
the irish people voted ‘no’ in a referendum on divorce in 1986.
hold a referendum
the government has promised to hold a referendum and let the people choose.

children.name: ballot x
children.definition: ballot when the members of an organization vote on sth by marking what they want on a piece of paper, especially in order to make sure that it is secret: cuộc bầu phiếu kín
examples: the result of the ballot showed that nurses were not in favour of a strike.
representatives were electedbyballot.
ballot of
he was elected by a ballot of all the teaching staff in the college.
secret ballot[when no-one knows what you voted for]
voting will be by secret ballot.
hold a ballot
it was decided to hold a ballot of all party members.

children.name: polls x
children.definition: polls a political election - used especially in news reports: cuộc bầu cử
examples: the party is still trying to recover from the losses it suffered at last year’s polls.
at the polls
richards won a huge victory at the polls.
the polls
voters have been flocking to the polls to elect a new president.

children.name: polling x
children.definition: polling the process of voting in a political election: quá trình bầu cử
examples: polling has been going on since 9 am.
the announcement of her resignation came just two days before polling was to begin.
polling day[uk] the day when an election is held
polling day is 30 may.
polling booth/ stationa place where people vote : phòng kín bầu cử
security was tight at the polling stations.

children.name: show of hands x
children.definition: show of hands when the people in a group are asked to vote informally by raising their hands: biểu quyết giơ tay
examples: a show of hands suggested that martins had little support.
she was elected by a show of hands.
her re-election to the committee was defeatedona show of hands.

children.name: the vote c1
children.definition: the vote the right to vote in an election: quyền bầu cử
examples: people are campaigning for civil rights and especially for the vote.
have the vote
the majority of immigrant workers do not have the vote.
get the vote
in 1928 in britain, women got the vote at 21 on equal terms with men.

children.name: have a vote u
children.definition: have a vote if you have a vote, you have the right to vote: có quyền bầu cử
examples: in britain, everyone over 18 has a vote.
the secretary is allowed to attend meetings, but does not have a vote.

children.name: suffrage x
children.definition: suffrage formal the right to vote in elections - use this especially to talk about people’s fight to be allowed to vote: quyền bầu cử
examples: there was a fierce struggle for women’s suffrage in britain early this century.
suffrage reforms took place in the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries.
universal suffragethe right of every adult in a country to vote : quyền bầu cử phổ thông
even now, not every country in europe has universal suffrage.

children.name: the franchise x
children.definition: the franchise formal the right to vote in political elections, especially for representatives in a parliament or similar law-making organization: quyền bầu cử
examples: the franchise was later extended to any person over 18 years old.
in 1918 the suffragistswon thefranchise for uk women over the age of 29.

children.name: enfranchise x
children.definition: enfranchise formal to give a person or a group of people the right to vote in political elections: trao, ban quyền bầu cử cho ai
examples: this legislation enfranchised many thousands of people.
the group works in developing countries to increase literacy and enfranchise women.
women in britain were first enfranchised in 1918.

children.name: disenfranchise x
children.definition: disenfranchise formal to take away sb’s right to vote in an election: tước quyền bầu cử của ai
examples: if you don’t get your name on the electoral register you may be disenfranchised.
disenfranchised[adj]đã bị tước quyền công dân; tước quyền bầu cử
not having the right to vote, or a similar right, or having had that right taken away
disenfranchised youth/ communities/ voters.

children.name: how many votes are made or received
the vote x
children.definition: the vote the total number of votes made in a political election: lượng phiếu bầu
examples: 63% of the vote went to the national party.
the green partygot/ took25% of the vote.
they are trying to capture the working-class vote (= to persuade those people to vote for them) .
sb’s share of the vote
once again, the democrats increased their share of the vote.

children.name: get a1
children.definition: get if a candidate receives or gets a particular number of votes, that is the number of people who have voted for him or her.
examples: the green party candidate got only one more vote than the socialists.

children.name: receive a2
children.definition: receive if a candidate receives or gets a particular number of votes, that is the number of people who have voted for him or her. receive is more formal than get:
examples: standord received 50% of the male vote.

children.name: poll x
children.definition: poll  to receive a particular number of votes in an election : nhận được bao nhiêu phiếu bầu
examples: he polled 23,579 votes.
the labour candidate polled 52% of the votes.
with nearly all the votes counted, mr soto had polled 67% of the vote.

children.name: run x
children.definition: run ra ứng cử
examples: ellis has not yet announced whether or not he will run.
run for
only eight percent of those standing for the national party were women.
run against
we’ve got an excellent candidate to run against harwood in the election.
run for president/ mayor/ office etc
there are rumors going around that i’m running for president, but they’re not true.

children.name: fight b2
children.definition: fight  to try very hard to get elected, especially when this is difficult: chiến đấu
examples: fight an election
the prime minister has decided to stay on to fight another election.
fight sb for sth
neil phillips will now fight adams for leadership of the party.

children.name: stand c2
children.definition: stand  ra ứng cử
examples: i hope ian will decide to stand because he’d make an excellent president.
stand for election[uk]
if you want to change the way the committee does things, you should stand for election yourself.
stand for parliament[uk] ra ứng cử vào quốc hội
he first stood for parliament in 1974 but failed to get in.

children.name: campaign c1
children.definition: campaign/kæmˈpeɪn/  the activities and advertising used over a period of time to persuade people to vote for a particular party or person : chiến dịch, cuộc vận động.
examples: throughout the campaign, baldwin looked the most likely to win.
election campaign: chiến dịch bầu cử
the endless public appearances are an inevitable part of an electioncampaign.
campaign[i verb] [c1] đi vận động
the prime minister will be campaigning in scotland next week.

children.name: electioneering x
children.definition: electioneering/ɪˌlekʃəˈnɪərɪŋ/  activities such as visiting places and talking to people to try to persuade them to vote for a particular person or party - use this especially when you think politicians arenotbeingsincerewhen they do this:
examples: cuộc vận động bầu cử ( đặc biệt là gian dối )
▪ modern electioneering is sophisticated and highly organised.
▪ critics have dismissed his visit to a shelter for the homeless as an obvious piece of electioneering.
electioneeringnoun[ u ]mainly disapproving cuộc vận động bầu cử
the activity of trying to persuade people to vote for a particular political party
_the m.p.'s speech was dismissed by her opponents as crude electioneering.

children.name: canvass x
children.definition: canvass/ˈkænvəs/  to go around an area or to people’s houses in order to find out if they intend to vote for you or your party and, if not, to try to persuade them that they should :
examples: đi vận động
▪ she was canvassing in the greenside area of town yesterday.
▪ i spent the whole afternoon canvassing voters.
canvass for
▪ i canvass for the democrats at election times.
canvassverbget support
[ i or t ] to try to get political support or votes, especially by visiting all the houses in an area
_i've been out canvassingforthe labour party every evening this week.
canvassnoun[ c ] cuộc vận động bầu cử; cuộc vận động bỏ phiếu

children.name: choose a government, leader, or representative by voting
elect b2
children.definition: elect to choose a government, leader, or representative by voting: bỏ phiếu bầu
examples: i think we should start by electing a new chairman.
elect sb leader/chariman/president etc
ken livingstone was elected mayor of london in may 2000.
we elected himasour representative.
she was elected chair of the board of governors.
the group elected one of its memberstobe their spokesperson.

children.name: vote in/ into b1
children.definition: vote in/into give sb a position of political power by voting for them : bầu cử ai
examples: vote sb/sth in
they always seem to vote in these corrupt, incompetent governments.
vote sb into power/ office
the conservatives have promised to cut taxes if they are voted into office.

children.name: re-elect x
children.definition: re-elect to elect sb to a position that they have had since the previous election: lại bầu (ai nắm chức vụ cũ)
examples: the chairman and treasurer have both been re-elected for another year.
re-elect sb as sth
simon mungford has been re-elected as party leader.

children.name: return x
children.definition: return  to elect a politician as a member of parliament - used especially in news reports: bầu (đại biểu) vào quốc hội
examples: only 96 conservative mps were returned at the last election.

children.name: nominate c1
children.definition: nominate to formally suggest that sb should become one of the people who will be voted for in an election : đề cử
examples: whoever is nominated today will go forward to the leadership elections.
nominate sb for sth
by now it was clear that bush was going to be nominated for president.
the film was nominatedforan academy award.
nominate sb as sth
i was nominated as chairman.
nomination[c noun] [c1] the name of a person who has been nominated:
all nominations must be in by three o'clock on march 21st.

children.name: have a vote b2
children.definition: have/ take a vote if a group of people have or take a vote, they each make it known which idea they agree with, as a formal way of deciding what to do: (nhóm người) tổ chức một cuộc bầu phiếu
examples: we couldn’t agree on a way forward, so we decided to have a vote.
have/ take a vote on
i think we should take a vote on whether or not to accept their offer.

children.name: put sth to the vote x
children.definition: put sth to the/ a vote to ask a group of people to vote on sth that has been discussed in order to come to an official decision about it: làm cuộc bầu cử
examples: let’s put it to the vote. all those in favour raise your hands.
when the matter was put to a vote, the staff voted overwhelmingly not to go on strike.
